data.title: Complete test
Testing DMP
Full dmp test3
Evaluation of 2D and WBG Material Quality toward Device Reliability
data.projectDescription:
This project provides the necessary measurement infrastructure to enable high confidence in manufacturing reliable devices containing advanced materials (herein 2D and wide-band gap materials). Reliability and provenance are often not considered early in electronics development, but they are essential steps of advanced electronic systems necessary for national security and defense applications.  This project addresses a significant pitfall in electronics for national security that are based on wide-band gap materials and builds out measurement framework for early adoption of next-generation electronics containing 2D materials as functional components.
First Challenge: Most GaN material and resulting high-frequency and power devices are manufactured overseas. This prevents these advanced devices from being utilized for domestic national security and defense needs because device and material provenance cannot be established.  Alternatively, materials and products from domestic suppliers are largely untested with regards to material quality, wafer-to-wafer reproducibility, and device performance. Together, these shortcomings mean that national security needs are effectively handicapped because modern GaN electronics cannot be used.

Second Challenge: While the use of 2D materials for microelectronics is called out in the Strategic Opportunities for U.S. Semiconductor Manufacturing Integration of 2D materials, and these materials are actively developed by Intel, TSMC and IMEC, material stress, strain and defect states, and deviations from theoretical performance are examples of challenges that all must be overcome to build reliability into these electronics as they are scaled up. Many of the material aspects that contribute to the advantageous properties of 2D materials (i.e., single-layer of exposed atoms) lead to a complex matrix of problems currently limiting implementation of 2D material-based electronics. Material integration, material stress, strain and defect states, and deviations from theoretical performance are examples of challenges that all must be overcome to build reliability into these electronics as they are scaled up.  

This project will (1) remove roadblocks in qualifying GaN electronics from domestic sources and provide guidance on measurements that address reliability in wide-band-gap materials, and (2) overcome the early challenges preventing use of 2D semiconductors and provide the essential metrologies for evaluating material quality and methods for evaluating reliability of 2D logic devices for ultimate CMOS scaling.

data.dataDescription: In collaboration with Intel, Sandia National Laboratory, and Kansas City National Security Campus this project will characterize semiconductor materials (both 2D and GaN) and provide materials characterization, reliability data and provenance information. Materials are tracked via spreadsheet. Metadata from instruments are maintained by the instrument owners and not the project itself.  Measurement data will include: electron microscopy data (Major EM formats, TIFs), scanning probe data (primarily proprietary formats), optical spectroscopy data (txt, csv format), electrical and transport data (txt, csv format). Also included are proprietary ToF-SIMS data and Labview data formats. Analyzed data formats are still being determined.

data.title: Test 2 ed
test 33
Gas Flow and Properties:  Standards and Models for Flow Metering Semiconductor Gases at Flows from 10 μL/min to 1 L/min
data.projectDescription: Numerous gases are used in the production of semiconductor chips, and the accurate metering of these gases into the process chamber is critical for maximizing device throughput and yield. Many of these gases are hazardous, and flow standards for hazardous gases do not exist, forcing the industry to rely on approximate “meter factors” to extrapolate a meter calibration carried out with nitrogen to the actual process gas. Our project will improve this situation by providing standards for the metering of hazardous gases. These will include physical models for meter performance across gas species and the gas thermophysical property data needed in those models; they will be validated by a flow standard operating with a range of semiconductor process gases. These models and properties will enable a meter calibrated with nitrogen to provide accurate measurements of hazardous process gases.
technicalResources:
Here is the revised list:

(685) Small fume hood
data.dataDescription:
This project produces data in two phases. The first phase is the thermophysical property measurements (i.e., density, heat capacity, viscosity (derived)) and modeling (i.e., thermodynamic equations of state and viscosity models) of a targeted list of semiconductor process gases. The results of these measurements will be published as Standard Reference Data.

The second phase of this project consists of measurements that result from a custom-built primary gas flow standard. These measurements are dependent on the results of the first phase and precise measurements of mass flow controller (MFC) dimensions, gas volume, and ambient temperature and pressure. Data from these measurements will enable the derivation of flow rates for the list of process gases and their uncertainties, which will, in turn, lead to models for any generic MFC. 

All data described above are recorded in text formats. Data processing is done with a mixture of Excel, Matlab, and custom scripts. Labview is used for data acquisition.
data.preservationDescription: Data will live on the CFS2 servers for the long term unless they are moved to the new Lake Erie server. The team plans on publishing as much as possible for preservation and archival purposes. For things that can’t be published a long-term location will need to be found or a disposition/destruction decision will be made.
data.dataAccess: Text/.csv files will be published via MIDAS/METIS and possibly as supplemental materials on publisher sites.
pathsURLs: local computers where data is acquired

data.title: Optical Impurity Analysis of Semiconductor Gases for Enhanced Quality Systems
data.projectDescription:
This project will create measurement technology, reference data and materials to perform trace impurity gas analysis at new levels of precision. The strategy is to develop measurement technologies, properties data and standards focused on contaminant identification to support uniform materials quality and traceability. New and updated documentary standards will assure manufacturers receiving materials of the provenance and consistency in the quality when purchased—and quickly alert stakeholders to changes in supply. New measurement technology with increased sensitivity and throughput for detection of gas contaminants can be deployed throughout the supply chain, including reliable and traceable isotopic analysis for material provenance.

If successful, impurity analysis on carbon monoxide (CO), carbon dioxide (CO2) and nitrous oxide (N2O) at the part-per-trillion (ppt) or lower level in commercial gases and after point-of-use gas purifiers is expected in 1–3 years. Benchmarked spectral reference data on hard-to-measure laser gases, etchants, and implant gases like sulfur hexafluoride (SF6), hydrogen fluoride (HF), and silane (SiH4) will be shared in widely used public databases for the direct application by industry in their optical diagnostics. Finally, gas primary standards for common trace impurities will be developed. After five years, the development of documentary standards and the dissemination of new NIST Standard Reference Materials® characterized by the new gas primary standards will enable the specialty gas industry to measure and verify higher quality gas products being sold directly to the semiconductor manufacturing industry.

data.title: Advanced Chemical Metrology for Semiconductor Cleaning Chemicals: Organic Contaminants, Native Particles and Precursors, and Rapid Particle and Impurity Characterization
data.projectDescription: The goal of the proposal is to develop metrology that enables the accurate monitoring of impurities in ultrapure water (UPW) at target levels called out by IRDS.  The realization of this goal during the project period will be demonstrated by: 1) the development of measurement procedures for critical organic contaminants at 1 ppb or below, 2) the development of measurement procedures for non-critical organics below 3 ppb, 3) identification and/or development of challenge materials with a range of chemical and physical properties for testing the efficiency of ultrafiltration systems, 4) the development of UPW0 for quantifying ultrafilter performance to particles as small as 1.5 nm at number densities below 1 × 105 L-1, and 5) development of methods for rapid surface particle-, and impurity detection and quantification in water/non-water solvents in the concentration range of interest.

data.title: Metrology of Purity and Contaminants in Solid Materials
data.projectDescription:
Chips manufacturers use a variety of high-purity solid materials, such as silicon, germanium, copper, gold, silver, GeSi, AlGaN, etc., in their processes.  Reliable chips require that these source materials be extremely pure and that they be qualified based on overall purity and priority contaminants.  For bulk materials (e.g., sputtering targets), direct solids analysis techniques, notably glow discharge mass spectrometry (GDMS), are used for purity evaluation.  GDMS is used because of its extremely low detection limits, which lead to unsurpassed quality in bulk purity evaluations.  However, relative measurement uncertainty for a given contaminant is often not better than a factor of two or more, because of the lack of matrix-matched certified reference materials with which to calibrate it.  Consequently, characterization of the materials used in the industry is not as robust as needed considering necessary changes in materials vendors and ever more stringent industry requirements.  Development of SRMs consisting of these extremely pure source materials and having certified purity assay values, as well as certified values for priority contaminants and information on spatial heterogeneity, will enable improved instrument calibration and validation, resulting in much better source materials characterization, which directly translate to higher productivity and lower risk of material waste. 
We will develop new Standard Reference Materials (SRMs), Reference Materials (RMs), and Research Grade Test Materials (RGTMs) of high-purity solids currently lacking in chips manufacturing, enabling more effective, efficient, and comparable characterizations of source materials, as well as process control improvements.  To achieve these goals, we will develop new NIST capabilities in glow discharge mass spectrometry (GDMS) and laser-based analytical methods, and we will significantly lower detection limits for existing NIST nuclear techniques.

data.dataDescription:
The data from this project will be generated as GDMS is developed and a RGTM is created. The RGTM will be the basis of an interlaboratory study where more data will be collected. 
Various 
Mass Spectrometry techniques will be used to generate elemental analysis data, spatial distribution of contaminant data and an actual purity assay.  
•	Glow Discharge Mass Spectrometry (GDMS): 1D spectrum, Mass vs. intensity (instrument does not exist today) 
•	Laser Induced Breakdown Spectroscopy (LIBS): 1D spectrum, Mass vs. intensity plus location data (x,y, and potentially z) 
•	Laser Ablation Inductively Coupled Plasma Mass Spectrometry (LA-ICP-MS): (same instrument as above, but is now operating in the break-down mode, therefore, same measurement axes as above instrument. 
•	Secondary Ion Mass Spectrometry (SIMS): 1D spectrum = Mass vs. intensity, and  2D mode = x-y raster, then gives same structure as LIBS. 

Nuclear techniques will allow for the following data generation:

•	Instrumental Neutron Activation Analysis (INAA):  1D plot where the x-axis = gamma ray energy / channel number, and the y-axis = gamma counts. AND 2D = coincidence measurement, you have energies on X&Y in the Z direction = timing of events.  
•	 Prompt Gamma Activation Analysis (PGAA): this is a subset of neutron analysis, subset of the INAA. Same gamma spectrum  
•	Neutron Depth Profiling (NDP) 
•	Common data formats for nuclear techniques:
o	Ascii, Canberra = .cnf file (proprietary) but convertible to IAEA format. Another format is the Ortec format 
o	 Analysis package = Genie 2000 (Canberra), Meastro (Ortec), PeakEZ from Oakridge. 
o	 BRF = US package that does complete spectrum analysis. Reads all formats. 

This nuclear spectra data will then be used to train ML models. These models will be used to build predictive capabilities and provide detector characterization.
data.preservationDescription: Preservation will occur by saving the data to the Lake Huron server ((\\lake-huron-smb.nist.gov\CHIPS 1.05 - Contaminants in Solids) and publishing models through MIDAS/METIS.
data.dataAccess: Beyond copies of the models preserved in MIDAS/METIS we also will publish the models in a model repository such as HuggingFace and possibly Weights and Biases.

data.title: Accurate Mapping of Thermal Properties at the Nanoscale
data.projectDescription:
Precise measurements of thermal properties at the nanoscale are needed for engineering of both advanced and heterogeneously integrated electronic devices but are currently unattainable. We will radically advance thermal properties metrology by developing a new tool for mapping thermal conductivity (η), interfacial thermal conductance (G) and chemical composition at the nanoscale, with high throughput (20 ms/pixel) and high precision (Δη <5%, ΔG <10%), concurrently. Thermal properties will be obtained by measuring the transient photothermal expansion of a sample with high spatial (≈10 nm) and temporal (≈4 ns) resolutions using NIST-made optomechanical AFM probes and wide-bandwidth detection. Synergistically, we will develop a far-field, super-resolution microscope capable of mapping thermal properties with ≈ 500 nm resolution, ultrahigh throughput ≈ 5 µs/pixel (≈ 24 million times faster than the state-of-the-art) and with depth sensitivity up to ≈ 100 μm.

This project will:
1.	Further develop the photothermal induced resonance (PTIR) microscope by modifying an AFM with optomechanical probes, a custom excitation laser and by expanding the spectral range of the detection laser while developing advanced data processing routines.
2.	Develop a Super-resolution photothermal microscope – which will use a CW visible detection laser and a high bandwidth detector to measure the time-domain thermalization of the sample at once, either in reflection or transmission.
technicalResources: NEW AFM with wide bandwidth controller and optical access
NEW High repetition rate-10 ns pulsed wavelength-tunable mid-IR excitation laser
NEW super resolution photothermal microscope (from Photothermal)
NEW 80 W fs near-IR tunable laser for 2-photon absorption
o	EKSPLA NT277 wavelength tunable pulsed mid-IR excitation laser (part of 644845)
o	M-squared Firefly wavelength tunable pulsed mid-IR excitation laser (part of 644845)

instruments.name: N116573
instruments.description_url: Light Conversion Carbide 40 with Orpheus OPA (part of 2-photon absorption pump-probe)
Toptica CTL 1500 CW tunable detection laser (part of 644845)

data.dataDescription:
The two experimental branches of this project leverage  the photothermal expansion physics associated to the absorption of short laser pulses in a sample.-absorption  
	
Both the AFM and super-resolution microscope will leverage wide bandwidth detection and electronics to measure, at once, the photothermal transient of the sample with high spatial and temporal resolutions. In the AFM, the optomechanical AFM probe tip transduces the local time-domain photothermal expansion of the sample and a detector which is fiber coupled to the probe senses the tip position. The super-resolution microscope uses a CW laser and a far-field detector to transduce the time-domain photothermal transient of the sample (i.e., changes of the sample refractive index) either in transmission or reflection. Data will consist of local nanoscale signal transients obtained either by maintaining the probe stationary and sweeping the excitation laser wavelength (local spectra), or by maintaining the excitation laser wavelength fixed and scanning the probe (AFM tip or CW detection laser) on the sample surface (2D nanoscale maps). 3D nanoscale maps will be obtained with the super-resolution microscope by scanning in 3D a two-photon absorption beam to generate a localized heat source at depth in the sample. Derived data from the raw data will yield maps of composition, thermal conductivity (η), interfacial thermal conductance (G), sample topography with nanoscale resolution.


When using conventional AFM probes for routine AFM measurements the dataset will be more limited and the data will be in proprietary formats (.axz). Preliminary two-photon absorption measurements will be stored in the HDF5 format. 

Pump-probe measurements use a Princeton Instruments proprietary format, SPE, and data after averaging is stored in HDF5 format. 
The non thermal data (AFM maps, IR spectra) are saved on Ansys instrument/Bruker proprietary format  .axz but those are typically much smaller files.
data.preservationDescription:
Jared: we plan to keep for the long term all data that shows some signal after averaging (which reduces the storage requirements by 10000x) and at our discretion keep raw data that we think may benefit from further processing (removing outlier frames, more sophisticated analysis).
 
Andrea and Vladimir: currently we save in progress data on cfs2e.nist.gov, then would organize it to the best of our ability there. Currently the time domain PTIR data can be evaluated offline after recording. In the future we hope to develop near real time routines for data visualization and analysis and would be able to determine more quickly if data are worth saving of not.
data.dataAccess: Published data will be made available via MIDAS.

data.title: Metrology of x-ray fundamental parameters for silicon microelectronics analysis
data.projectDescription:
We propose to employ NIST-designed advanced x-ray spectrometers, arrays of cryogenic, superconducting x-ray microcalorimeters, to measure x-ray fluorescence spectra of numerous pure elements and chemical compounds of relevance to the semiconductor industry. The excellent energy resolution and high efficiency of the transition-edge sensors (TESs) make them ideal for quantitative analysis of the fundamental atomic data that govern the spectra. 
The objective of the current work is to measure fundamental atomic data about x-ray emissions, and to do so with metrological accuracy and careful understanding of uncertainties. The resulting data will be the basis for a new reference database, either in the NIST SRD series, or as a CHIPS-specific data product. If successful, this database would expand upon the existing SRD-128 or produce a new SRD product.
data.dataDescription:
The project will be generating data through both experimental and computational methods. Experimentally, the project utilizes a Transition-Edge Sensor (TES) array to measure the X-ray fluorescence spectra of various materials. The TES array is a cryogenic microcalorimeter that detects the temperature rise caused by X-ray photons, which is then converted into an electrical signal. The measurement process involves exposing a sample to an X-ray source, and the TES array detects the fluorescence X-rays emitted by the sample. The resulting data is a time series of pulse records, which are then processed to extract the X-ray energies and their corresponding uncertainties. The processed data is stored in a custom binary file format, known as "ljh files", which contains metadata and raw 16-bit numbers representing the timing information and temperature data. The experimental data will be distilled down to energy distributions or spectra, which will be the primary data product.

Computationally, the project involves simulations of atomic theory to calculate X-ray energies, which will be used to support the experimental measurements. The computational data will be generated using High-Performance Computing (HPC) resources, such as the Blackbird, Redwing, or other clusters. The simulations will produce data on the theoretical X-ray energies and their uncertainties, which will be used to validate the experimental results. The computational data will likely be stored in a format suitable for HPC output, although the specific file format is not mentioned. The project also involves data processing and analysis using custom algorithms, such as the pulse processing algorithm, which will be used to extract the X-ray energies from the experimental data. The algorithm and simulation data may be published through the METAS portal, allowing for easy discovery and access by other researchers. Overall, the project will generate a range of data types, from raw experimental data to processed spectra and computational simulations, which will be stored in various file formats and made available through different channels.

data.title: Metrology of x-ray fundamental parameters for silicon microelectronics analysis
data.projectDescription:
We propose to employ NIST-designed advanced x-ray spectrometers, arrays of cryogenic, superconducting x-ray microcalorimeters, to measure x-ray fluorescence spectra of numerous pure elements and chemical compounds of relevance to the semiconductor industry. The excellent energy resolution and high efficiency of the transition-edge sensors (TESs) make them ideal for quantitative analysis of the fundamental atomic data that govern the spectra. 
The objective of the current work is to measure fundamental atomic data about x-ray emissions, and to do so with metrological accuracy and careful understanding of uncertainties. The resulting data will be the basis for a new reference database, either in the NIST SRD series, or as a CHIPS-specific data product. If successful, this database would expand upon the existing SRD-128 or produce a new SRD product.

data.title: test 1
Advanced Metrology to Enable Next-Generation EUV Photoresists
data.projectDescription:
Project Description:
The semiconductor industry continues to push for smaller features, more integration, and increased yield. New photoresist chemistries and advances in extreme ultraviolet lithography are enabling this trend. However, this is inhibited by a lack of measurements describing heterogeneities in chemistry that contribute to the quality of photoresist patterns at these smaller dimensions. This includes fundamental questions into how the EUV exposure changes the resist chemistry and its spatial extent, and the underlying mechanisms that produce those changes. Our proposed NIST team will characterize the properties of advanced lithographic materials, measure nanoscale chemical distributions, and study the patterning process in situ. This will be accomplished by further developing a suite of metrology techniques which have tailored sensitivity to both the chemistry and structure of the photoresists and how the exposure processes influence critical dimensions and edge roughness. Completion of the project will provide industry with a roadmap to rapid characterization of new EUV resist formulations and processing approaches that will further enable high yield manufacturing and accelerate US industry competitiveness in this space.

This project will:
1.	Conduct soft X-ray whole film spectroscopy (reflectivity) and vertical depth profiling for photoresists and underlayers: 
a.	Produce an absorption spectroscopy data library for EUV and DSA materials
b.	compare spectroscopic collection modalities including electron yield, transmission, and low-dose imaging.
2.	EUV latent image characterization using soft X-ray scattering
a.	Develop soft X-ray scattering approaches to display of chemical heterogeneity within latent images (i.e., three-dimensional spatial extent of chemical changes undergone by EUV photoresists during exposure and subsequent processing steps), with nanoscale resolution.
b.	Beamline modifications (camera upgrade and sample holder redesign from 4 to 5 axes) to enable fully three-dimensional measurements of the latent image.
3.	Characterization of block copolymers for EUV pattern rectification - Correlate commensurability between the block co-polymer (BCP) and the EUV pattern relates to the device line-edge roughness (LER).
4.	Real-time AFM probe methods for monitoring of photoresist development – in situ AFM measurements of the resist development process using NIST’s nanophotonic AFM probes and on-chip integrated microdisk photonic resonators for readout.
technicalResources: Brookhaven National Laboratory NSLS-II  Beamline SST-1
NIST RSoXS measurement station and Brookhaven National Laboratory
data.dataDescription:
The beamline data will consist of x-ray absorption spectra. Spectroscopy data are organized into data libraries under different material types. Scattering measurements will produce images, from which an important parameter, the line edge roughness (LER) will be extracted. pyHyperscattering  (https://github.com/usnistgov/PyHyperScattering), is an open-source data reduction library that is used by this project.

The AFM data will consist of images, but may also contain other data types. The contract to this new AFM has not yet been awarded, so it is difficult provide a data description at this time.

CFS2E is backed-up by OISM

Beamline data is also saved on BNL central file server.


AFM data will be saved on the control computer.

data.title: Atom Probe Tomography: Nanostructured Semiconductor Materials, Interfaces, and Devices
data.projectDescription:
The semiconductor industry requires sub-nm, 3-dimensional quantitative elemental mapping of materials, nanoscale structures, and devices with high analytical sensitivity for process development, failure analysis, and competitive engineering. Atom probe tomography (APT) is recognized by industry as the method that can address these goals. However, commercially available atom probe tomography instruments and methodologies are inadequate. This project will make critical metrology advancements in APT instrumentation, experimental methods, data analysis, and modeling and simulation. With these new tools, industry will increase yield, improve device performance, and accelerate time to market. 

This project will:
1.	Improve instrument design
2.	Publish best-practice guides, white papers for industry
3.	NIST data on optimal specimen geometry, data collection parameters, and analysis techniques.
a.	Optimize extraction wavelength for each material
b.	Measurement standardization
4.	Measurements on complex materials, structures, and devices (i.e., not test samples)
5.	A simulation tool for modeling specimen apex electrostatics.
6.	(possibly) tech transfer of new next-generation APT instrument
technicalResources: NEW Sum frequency generation ultrafast laser source
data.dataDescription:
There are four general sources of data:
1.	Atom Probe Tomography (ATP) Data (raw)
a.	Legacy ATP format = RHIT. This is a proprietary data format which will go away at some point.
b.	New ATP format = “ATP”. Also proprietary, but some parts of this raw data is exportable to something more open like Python and MatLab.
2.	APT analysis data: 
a.	Analysis data in proprietary formats (POS, ePOS).
b.	Mass spectrum range files (.txt)
c.	Analysis states (.analysis)

3.	Support electron microscopy data. 
a.	Focused ion beam (FIB) data – these are in TIFF formats. 
b.	Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images– Images are in TIFF format. 
c.	Scanning/Transmission electron microscopy (S/TEM) data: May contain images, diffraction patterns, 4D STEM data, tomography data, EELS data, EFTEM images, other new formats possible with the new instruments.
d.	X-ray spectroscopy data format:
i.	Zeiss LEO SEM (927910) has an EDAX system and generate data in EDAX format
BMF Auriga FIB (936855) has an EDAX system and generate data in EDAX format
ii.	 New CHIPS TEM 1 is a Talos, it will have a DualX detector, format unknown right now.
iii.	New CHIPS TEM 2 is a Spectra, it will have a SuperX detector, format unknown right now.

4.	Simulation data:
a.	Software: Matlab . File format” “FIG” file and text files. Expected volume ~  500 GB/year. 
b.	Software: Ansys. Package is “Lumerical.” Software tool is called “Charge”. Have not yet had a successful run, so file format/volume unknown.
data.preservationDescription: A local copy of the instrument data (for both ATPs, 647-owned microscopes) are kept with the instrument, but is automatically copied to a read-only file location (Boulder NAS) via MML-data plumbing. 647-owned electron microscopy data is part of the electron microscopy (EM) Nexus. The preservation description can be found in the NexusLIMS DMP (ref. MIDAS EDI record #2245).
data.dataAccess:
Presently, data generated by Nexus microscopes (all 647-owned) microscopes are discoverable via NexusLIMS (ref. MIDAS EDI record #2245). There are plans to add new microscopes, as well as BMF-owned microscopes to NexusLIMS to make those data discoverable. Data acquired as a part of a CRADA will not be made discoverable.

As for simulation data there are no plans to make these discoverable, but we hope to discuss this soon.

data.title: Critical Dimension Small Angle X-ray Scattering (CDSAXS) for Next Generation in-line Metrology
data.projectDescription:
The semiconductor industry is in need of new in-line dimensional metrology methods to measure the size and shape of nanoscale structures such as gate-all-around transistors, 3D-NAND, and 3D-DRAM for process control. 

The NIST-developed CDSAXS method has recently been commercialized for characterization of 3D-NAND contact holes and has the potential to provide need measurements of GAA nanosheet transistor and through silicon vias (TSV). The primary limitation of CDSAXS is measurement throughput due to the lack of compact X-ray sources with sufficient brightness. The scattering intensity, and thus the measurement time, scales with the square of the height of the structure   
The industry needs NIST to use their unique expertise in the CDSAXS method to provide continued support through advanced measurement and standard development. 

There are three thrusts to the project: 1) Demonstration of CDSAXS on next generation devices such as GAA nanosheets and TSVs using a best available laboratory SAXS system and synchrotron facilities, 2) Collaboration with X-ray source developers to identify potential game changing X-ray technology and to direct their efforts to the CDSAXS application, and 3) Development and certification of new IP-neutral industrial-relevant test structures and leveraging of NSTC capabilities.
data.dataDescription:
Data is X-ray scattering data – for a single sample, there would be ~100 incident angle/set up (each set is from 500-1000 MB per sample, but is highly compressible. The conversion to images is a few MB each). At that point there is a processing step that turns all the scattering data into an image. Users care about being able to perform inverse modeling to create the same structure that will create this observed scattering pattern. The end user cares about seeing the share distribution model. The modeling people want to see the raw data. 
Monte Carlo Markov chain (reverse calculations by inverse iterative modelling) is a few GB in size if/when a full run is saved.
data.preservationDescription: Everything is saved on ResData, nothing is deleted

data.title: test 3
Electron-Solid Interactions
data.projectDescription:
•	The accuracy of SEM (scanning electron microscopy) is limited by uncertainties associated with our poor knowledge of electron-solid interactions. 
•	The predicted inelastic mean free paths of existing models differ by a factor of 5 or more in the relevant low energy regime.  
•	Predicted secondary electron yields for important CHIPS-relevant materials differ by factors of 2 or 3. Secondary electron yield measurements are variable from laboratory to laboratory. This renders quantitative interpretation difficult. 
•	Industry needs good simulations of backscattered electron yields from beams of 30 keV to 100 keV because new technologies have deeply buried interfaces. 
•	Need models that can account for charging. 
 
Project goals/to-do: 
•	Project will finish building and will characterize a new yield measurement system.
•	Yield measurement system will produce secondary-electron and backscattered-electron yields and energy spectra as functions of beam energy and beam angle on various materials. Data will be used to test and refine models.
•	Project will initially plan to pattern the upper surface of thin silicon membranes in the NIST NanoFab. Pattern topography will be measured in secondary electron and transmitted modes. Comparison will be used to test and refine models.
•	New models: Will use DFT with the Bethe-Salpeter equation to compute electron energy loss functions and derive scattering properties. Electron-phonon scattering and charging processes will be modeled. Refine and iterate as data become available. 
•	Validated beam-solid interaction models will be incorporated into a simulator (JMONSEL) where they can be used for quantitative metrology.
•	Publishing yield and topographic data on well-characterized CHIPS-relevant materials: Cu, Ni, Ag, Au, Si, and others to start, insulators (SiO2, Si3N4) later.
•	Project will enable simulation of e-beam measurements of devices with buried interfaces.
data.dataDescription:
The following assumptions were used:
•	(important) Spectra ~60MB each
•	(Important) Images 10 MB to 10 GBs
•	(important) Mathematica notebooks 100’s of MB
•	(important) DFT+ BSE = kB per output
•	(important) Dielectric as a function of both momentum transfer and angle. 
•	(important) LabView codes on GitLab (100 GB)
•	(unimportant) Computation data has lots of wavefunction files that are large.
data.preservationDescription: (1) Enterprise backup of local host, (2) CFS2E and Elwood are both automatically backed up. (3) OneDrive is used as a mirror for local host, (4) GitLab and Box have their own enterprise back-up solutions (we believe). (5) DFT+BSE data (on Raritan) are not backed up. Final optical spectra files will be sent to OneDrive, which is Office 365 backed up.
data.dataAccess:
No plans to make data discoverable and accessible beyond internal NIST team for now. However, this team would like help developing repositories to disseminate Yield spectra, and dimensional measurements for the external community. Have not thoroughly thought about publicly disseminating the JMONSEL code for the fear of having to provide tech support (writing and disseminating open-source software is not the goal of this project). 

NISTMonte, JMONSEL, and many other packages live in the larger EPQ project, and they call each other’s routines extensively at the following location on GitHub - https://github.com/jsvillar/EPQ
pathsURLs:
•	CFS2E path(s): ): \\cfs2e.nist.gov\68_PML\681\681A\internal\jvillar\linewidth\jvillar\projects\SEMmodeling\JMONSEL_projects\CHIPS  (Likely archive location)
•	Elwood path(s): \\elwood\681\internal\MND_Projects\YieldMeasurement
•	OneDrive path(s):
o	//nistgov-my.sharepoint.com/:f:/r/personal/inm4_nist_gov/Documents/Desktop/DFT_BSE_complex_dielectric_function?csf=1&web=1&e=WNc2qV
o	//nistgov-my.sharepoint.com/:f:/r/personal/jvillar_nist_gov/Documents/My Documents/ActiveProjects/CHIPS?csf=1&web=1&e=1KeYuM
•	GitLab path(s): https://gitlab.nist.gov/gitlab/oism_lab_automation_team/electronyieldinvacuum/rfa 
•	GitHub - https://github.com/jsvillar/EPQ
•	Box URL(s): YamaneMeasurementIntercomparisons2023 | Powered by Box
•	Local host (ipaddress+paths): \\129.6.128.68\d$\jvillar\localProjects\ActiveProjects\CHIPS
Note: Data may be stored here long-term or short-term depending on the reason it is here. In either case

this machine is subscribed to the nightly back-up service. The Two reasons: 
1.	During long-running simulations

scripts and outputs are stored on a local drive to avoid slow network communication and the risk of network outages interrupting the simulation. Even though OneDrive files are both local and in the cloud
OneDrive copes poorly with files that are frequently updated (like a simulation output file that is updated with new results every few seconds or minutes). For example
it may try to keep a very long file history with thousands of versions
and it can compete for file access: OneDrive to upload the latest version
the simulator to append the latest result. In this case the data are stored here during the simulation

then transferred to the ActiveProjects/CHIPS folder on OneDrive.
2.	A folder may exceed OneDrive’s limits for either size of data or number of files. In that case

it is stored here and kept synchronized (by periodically manually running Microsoft SyncToy) with a copy in the JMONSEL_projects\CHIPS folder on CFS2E.
•	Raritan path(s): /wrk/inm4 (Data is normally only stored here temporarily before being transferred to OneDrive) –

data.title: Overcoming Barriers: Nanoscale Interface Metrology and Electrical Characterization for Advanced Electronics
data.projectDescription:
•	Development of new microelectronics and semiconductor devices based on thin-film, nanostructured and multi-layer materials is hampered by the lack of understanding of electric fields in these structures. Models of device behavior, including failure analysis, are limited because designers assume each material has the properties of its pure bulk material.
•	Atomic scale measurement of electric field is possible with aberration-corrected scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) and an appropriate detector but requires careful collection and processing of extremely large data sets and is complicated by interfaces.
•	Development of this measurement for application to thin-film and multilayer device interfaces will provide an atomic level understanding of electric fields at interfaces and enable accurate prediction of band offsets for continued development of ever-shrinking devices.
Project Goals:
•	Procure an aberration-corrected STEM with segmented and pixelated electron detectors.
•	Fabricate TEM lamella from representative multi-layer materials and devices; identify techniques that minimize preparation related artifacts.
•	Collect and analyze 4-D STEM datasets to determine optimum data collection conditions.
•	Compare and optimize data analysis methods.
•	Deliver electric field maps of device interfaces to partners in the CMOS and WBG industries. 
•	Compare measurements of a single specimen from multiple STEM instruments using different detectors and detector-specific data formats, to develop standardized measurement procedures.
•	Analyze the impact of sample preparation parameters and instrument settings on measurement results to establish standardized procedures.
•	Publish data capture, data reduction and analysis software through public channels (journals, NIST servers or services).
technicalResources:
fast networking for large dataset transport.
Research Equipment Network (REN) for raw data access and backup.
NexusLIMS integration for FIB

microscopy data and sample tracking.
Globus and SciServer have strong potential for the data reduction “app”.
data.dataDescription:
•	FIB and SEM images of specimens (10 GB/year) 
•	4-D STEM diffraction patterns (20 TB/year) in vendor/detector-specific data formats (dm3, dm4, JEOL, TIF)
•	Instrument settings and data collection metadata (1 GB/year)
•	Electric field maps of specimens (10 GB/year)
•	Version-controlled software source code (1 GB/year)
data.preservationDescription:
•	Raw data on the REN is mirrored to BoulderNAS. Another copy sent to division network drive (cfs2w), which is backed up.
•	Intermediate/processed data is on Alexana’s and Edwin’s computers, which are backed up daily (Edge Monitor).
•	Publication-quality data is also on localhost, backed up daily at noon.

data.title: Extreme Ultraviolet Scatterometry
data.projectDescription:
https://inet.nist.gov/files/euv-scatterometrybarnesproject-planinetpdf/pdf 
Industry roadmaps show that infrared, visible, and ultraviolet approaches will barely yield adequate results for Gate All Around (GAA) devices and fail for Complementary Field Effect Transistors (CFETs); our goal is demonstrating the feasibility of extreme ultraviolet (EUV,  = 13.5 nm) scatterometry in the 10 nm to 150 nm spectral region for industrial tech transfer. For industrial optics-based measurements such as scatterometry, focused research must begin now to address high-throughput measurements of the dimensional properties of new materials and devices such as GAA and CFETs.  This non-destructive technique will allow the characterization of surfaces, buried features, interfaces, and devices with increased resolution, sensitivity, accuracy, and throughput.  Only using these shorter wavelengths can process control metrology keep pace with cutting-edge and future microelectronics and semiconductor manufacturing, while maintaining a competitive U.S. advantage. Present optical methods cannot go below 10 nm in feature sizes.


This project will: 
•	Develop two new measurement capabilities: 
o	Synchrotron-based EUV ellipsometry for thin film optical properties characterization  
o	Lab-based EUV Scatterometry for dimensional and materials measurements of patterned features 
 
•	Use coupled wave theory to determine the sensitivity to scattering (evaluate parameters such as wavelengths, incident angles, polarizations, and diffraction orders) from specimen of varying dimensional and material parameters. These simulations will also demonstrate feasibility of scatterometry in the EUV band. 
•	Conduct EUV diffractometry in collaboration with Prof. Margaret Murnane Group at the University of Colorado 
•	Create a Mueller Matrix ellipsometer, which will be used to demonstrate spectroscopic ellipsometry characterization of thickness and optical constants of thin films on a substrate.
•	Establish CRADA with companies like KLA and Onto Innovation 
•	Compare Synchrotron results with Tabletop EUV High-harmonic generation (HHG) results. 
•	Perform Tabletop EUV HHG scatterometry for CRADA partners, NSTC, and refine measurement techniques.
technicalResources: EUV HHG laser - KM Labs RAEA + XUUS 5
2 sample positioning stages for High vacuum and ultra-high vacuum
Pair of HV-compatible custom-built four-bounce mirror mounts rotatable about a central axis
New HV chamber housing the HV motion stages and polarizer mounts and associated turbomolecular pumps
UHV compatible EUV sensitive CCD camera
data.dataDescription:
The project’s data will be generated via multiple instruments, but typically elliposometry data is text based, diffractometers produce images, and scatterometry also produces text formats.
All output formats will be open.
data.preservationDescription: CFS2E and OneDrive are both enterprise services backed up by OISM.
data.dataAccess:
•	Internally: Data is available in the shared OneDrive, Teams, OneNote, email, paper notebook
•	Externally: Data will be expanded into publications. Fitting algorithms are published to https://github.com/usnistgov/pySCATMECH. Data from this project will be available through https://www.nist.gov/metis.
•
